Integrating a vector field

In a similar manner to the case of a scalar field, a vector field may be integrated over a surface. Two common types of integral are \(\displaystyle\int_S \underline{F}(\underline{r}) \cdot \underline{dS}\) and \(\displaystyle\int_S \underline{F}(\underline{r}) \times \underline{dS}\) which integrate to a scalar and a vector respectively. Again, when \(\underline{dS}\) is expressed appropriately, the expression will reduce to a double integral. The form \(\displaystyle\int_S \underline{F}(r)\cdot \underline{dS}\) has many important applications, e.g. the flux of a vector field such as an electric or magnetic field.

Example

Evaluate the integral \[\displaystyle\int_A ( x^2 y \underline{i} + z \underline{j} + (2x+y) \underline{k}) \cdot \underline{dS}\] over the area \(A\) where \(A\) is the square \(0 \le x \le 1\), \(0 \le y \le 1\), \(z=0\).

Solution

On \(A\), the unit normal is \(dx\, dy\, \underline{k}\) \begin{eqnarray*} &\therefore&\displaystyle\int_A ( x^2 y \underline{i} + z \underline{j} + (2x+y) \underline{k}) \cdot (\underline{k} \;dx\, dy) \\ &=& \displaystyle\int_{y=0}^1 \displaystyle\int_{x=0}^1 (2x+y) \; dx\, dy = \displaystyle\int_{y=0}^1 \left[\phantom{\dfrac{1}{1}}\!\!\! x^2 + xy \right]_{x=0}^1 dy\qquad\qquad\qquad\qquad\qquad\qquad\qquad\qquad \\ &=& \displaystyle\int_{y=0}^1 (1+y) dy = \left[ y + \frac{1}{2}y^2 \right]_0^1 = \frac{3}{2} \end{eqnarray*}

Example

Evaluate \(\displaystyle\int_A \underline{r} \cdot \underline{dS}\) where \(A\) represents the surface of the unit cube \(0\le x \le 1\),\(0 \le y \le 1\),\(0 \le z \le 1\) and \(\underline{r}\) represents the vector \(x\underline{i}+y\underline{j}+z\underline{k}\) .

Solution

The vector \(\underline{dS}\) (in the direction of the normal vector) will be a constant vector on each face, but will be different for each face. On the face \(x=0\) , \(\underline{dS}=-dy\, dz\, \underline{i}\) and the integral on this face is \(\qquad\displaystyle \displaystyle\int_{z=0}^1 \displaystyle\int_{y=0}^1 (0\underline{i}+y\underline{j}+z\underline{k})\cdot (- dy\, dz\, \underline{i} ) = \displaystyle\int_{z=0}^1 \displaystyle\int_{y=0}^1 0 \; dy\, dz = 0 \) Similarly on the face \(y=0\), \(\underline{dS}=-dx\, dz\, \underline{j}\) and the integral on this face is \(\qquad\displaystyle \displaystyle\int_{z=0}^1 \displaystyle\int_{x=0}^1 (x\underline{i}+0\underline{j}+z\underline{k})\cdot (- dx\, dz\, \underline{j} ) = \displaystyle\int_{z=0}^1 \displaystyle\int_{x=0}^1 0 \; dx\, dz = 0 \) Furthermore on the face \(z=0\), \(\underline{dS}=-dx\, dy\, \underline{k}\) and the integral on this face is \(\qquad\displaystyle \displaystyle\int_{x=0}^1 \displaystyle\int_{y=0}^1 (x\underline{i}+y\underline{j}+0\underline{k})\cdot (- dx\, dy\, \underline{k} ) = \displaystyle\int_{x=0}^1 \displaystyle\int_{y=0}^1 0 \; dx\, dy = 0 \) On these three faces, the contribution to the integral is thus zero. However, on the face \(x=1\), \(\underline{dS}=+dy\, dz\, \underline{i}\) and the integral on this face is \(\qquad\displaystyle \displaystyle\int_{z=0}^1 \displaystyle\int_{y=0}^1 (1\underline{i}+y\underline{j}+z\underline{k})\cdot (+ dy\, dz\, \underline{i} ) = \displaystyle\int_{z=0}^1 \displaystyle\int_{y=0}^1 1 \;dy\, dz = 1 \) Similarly, on the face \(y=1\), \(\underline{dS}=+dx\, dz\, \underline{j}\) and the integral on this face is \(\qquad\displaystyle \displaystyle\int_{z=0}^1 \displaystyle\int_{x=0}^1 (x\underline{i}+1\underline{j}+z\underline{k})\cdot (+ dx\, dz\, \underline{j} ) = \displaystyle\int_{z=0}^1 \displaystyle\int_{x=0}^1 1 \; dx\, dz = 1 \) Finally, on the face \(z=1\), \(\underline{dS}=+dx\, dy\, \underline{k}\) and the integral on this face is \(\qquad\displaystyle \displaystyle\int_{y=0}^1 \displaystyle\int_{x=0}^1 (x\underline{i}+y\underline{j}+1\underline{k})\cdot (+ dx\, dy\, \underline{k} ) = \displaystyle\int_{y=0}^1 \displaystyle\int_{x=0}^1 1 \; dx\, dy = 1 \) Adding together the contributions gives \(\displaystyle\int_A \underline{r} \cdot \underline{dS}= 0 + 0 + 0 + 1 + 1 + 1=3\)
